The Master and Fellows of Pembroke College, Cambridge (CC BY-NC 4.0)

summary.seg: Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 258 is a composite manuscript comprised of several originally separate parts created in England between the 12th and 15th centuries. Among the many and various texts in the manuscript are stories about Christian saints, texts on theology, confession and penance, Alexander the Great, natural history, Christian apocrypha, moral fables, penance, short poems, and brief medical recipes.

Among the many interesting features of Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 258 is its medieval binding: the volume does not have a typical medieval binding where the quires have been laced into hard boards covered with leather, limp-parchment or tawed skin, but instead has a home-made binding of an envelope of limp-parchment and linen stuffed with documents. The binding was constructed by taking a piece of semi-limp parchment a little more than twice the width of a leaf in the volume, laying it flat, placing several mid-15th century documents pasted together on top of the semi-limp parchment, then placing a piece of linen on top of the documents and sewing all three layers together with a linen thread. The three-layered cover was then folded in half (with the linen on the inside), and the quires were attached to the binding by stab-sewing through the full-thickness of the binding. The sewing to close the fore edge of the rear cover came apart after the cover was finished and the various layers of the cover are now loose at the rear of the manuscript. Some of the documents that were pasted together to line the cover have become separate in the intervening centuries and contain dating clauses for the reign of King Edward IV (reg. 1461-1470 and 1471-1483). The unusual format of the cover suggests that it may have been assembled by a former owner of the manuscript. A likely candidate for the former owner and binder is an otherwise unknown 'Goodwyn' who wrote his name on the outside of the front cover, and the inside of the rear cover and may have also written his name on the inside of the front cover where it is rendered as 'Goodwin 1496' in what may actually be a slightly later hand.

Little is known about the provenance of the manuscript, since it does not appear in any records of the holdings of Pembroke College library before 1898. It may have arrived a little earlier than that, since an 1879 Pembroke College bookplate is found on the inside of the front cover, but as bookplates were often used for several years after they were printed, the bookplate alone is not sufficient to establish an earlier date of acquisition.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: The book-block is comprised of medieval parchment leaves deriving from seven originally separate sources. The outer surface of the cover is semi-limp parchment. The inner surface of the cover is woven linen cloth stitched onto the semi-limp parchment and forming a pocket or envelope structure. The space between the semi-limp parchment outer cover and the cloth inner cover has been lined with documents made of medieval paper and parchment.

foliation.note: Foliated in the upper outer corner of each recto in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals.

collation.p:
Composite manuscript comprised of several parchment booklets of separate origin now bound together. Leaves in Quires 14 and 15 are misbound. Quire 14, a quire of four leaves (ff. 123-126), consists of two sequential rather than nested bifolia, and the second bifolium, the present ff. 125r-126v has been bound inside out; the leaves in Quire 14 should be read ff. 123, 124, 126, 125. Quire 15 is a quire of 7 leaves (ff. 127-133), three nested bifolia and a singleton (f. 133) after the 6th leaf; the singleton is misbound and should be the first leaf in the quire; the leaves in Quire 15 should be read ff. 133, 127-132.
Quire 120 (ff. 1-20) |
Quire 210 (ff. 21-30)
Quire 310-2 (ff. 31-38: 9th and 10th leaves cancelled)
Quire 48-3 (ff. 39-43: 6th, 7th, and 8th leaves cancelled) |
Quire 58 (ff. 44-51) |
Quire 6six(ff. 52-57: gap between the 3rd and 4th leaf) |
Quires 7-810 (ff. 58-77)
Quire 914 (ff. 78-91) |
Quire 108 (ff. 92-99)
Quire 118-2 (ff. 100-105: 6th and 7th leaves cancelled)
Quire 128 (ff. 106-113)
Quire 138+1 (ff. 114-122: 1 leaf added after the 8th leaf) |
Quire 144 (ff. 123-126)
Quire 156+1 (ff. 127-133: 1 leaf added after the 6th leaf)
Quire 168 (ff. 134-141)

p.formula: 120 | 210 310-2 (9th and 10th cancelled) 48-3 (6th, 7th, and 8th cancelled) | 58 | 6six (gap between the 3rd and 4th leaf) | 7-810 914 | 108 118-2 (6th and 7th cancelled) 128 138+1(1 leaf added after the 8th) | 144 156+1 (1 leaf added after the 6th) 168

note.p: Quires numbered 1-16 in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals; this quire designation sequence probably added in the 19th century.

binding.p: Late-15th or early-16th century binding. The binding of Pembroke College MS 258 consists of three layers, each slightly larger than the largest bifolium in the volume, so that when the layers were stacked, sewn together, and folded in half, they formed a simple cover for the book-block. From outside to inside the cover, the three layers consist of: 1) a layer of semi-limp parchment; 2) a 'lining' layer made from layers of parchment documents from the reign of Edward IV pasted together; 3) a layer of linen cloth. The three layers are arranged a little like a quilted blanket, with the limp-parchment layer serving as the outer cover, the document layer functioning as the 'padding' or 'wadding' in the quilt, and the linen cloth layer serving as the 'backing', and forming the layer in contact with the text leaves. The three layers were originally sewn together all the way around the border of the cover with a linen thread; the sewing at the rear of the volume has since broken, and the various layers of the cover-structure are now exposed.

The quires of Pembroke College MS 258 are stab-sewn to the composite cover with vertical tacking stitches through the full thickness of the spine. Two paper labels fixed to the spine with an adhesive: a paper label with the Pembroke shelfmark '258' handwritten in ink, and a paper label with a handwritten list of some of the texts the spine.

The inside of the front cover contains:
The name 'Goodwin' and the date '1496' in dark ink (this name also appears faintly on the front cover, and on the linen cover layer at the rear of the volume
A note in ink 'bonum est Missam celebrare pro defunctis'
The number '120' struck out and the number '258' written in bright pink ink
A note in ink 'Evang: Iohannis Lat: cum Comm: Bedae et Augustini'
A Pembroke College bookplate, mounted horizontally, dated 1879
Residue of a small oval wax seal or dark book label

The documents used as the inner padding for the binding date from the reign of Edward IV (reg. 4 March 1461 to 3 October 1470 and 11 April 1471 to 9 April 1483). The documents mention the building of a chamber in Pety Alley (now Petty Wales), and also Blakmanstrete, Suthwerk, and Kenstrete. Blakmanstrete, Suthwerk, and Kenstrete are all places in London on the south bank of the river Thames. These documents are described in more detail in Part 8 in this record.
This binding is similar in construction to Cambridge, University Library, Add. MS 6866, although Add. MS 6866 has an inner layer of parchment rather than linen around a pad of documents.
For further reading on this binding see N. Hadgraft, 'English Fifteenth Century Book Structures', unpubl. PhD thesis (University College London, 1998), esp. p. 250 and n. 162.

provenance.p: In the upper margin of f. 85r there is a note in a ?mid-15th century hand: 'Alexander presbiter constat istum librum'.

The name 'Goodwyn' appears 3 times: as 'Goodwyn' on the front cover; as 'Goodwin' on the inside of the left cover with the date '1496'; and 'Goodwyn' on the cloth cover layer at the rear of the volume, probably a former owner, or perhaps the original compiler of the volume.

acquisition.p: It is not known when or from whom Pembroke College obtained MS 258. The manuscript appears in H. Schenkl's Bibliotheca Patrum Latinorum Britannica (1898), no. 2490, but does not appear in any of the earlier inventories of Pembroke's library holdings.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Pembroke College, Cambridge (1905), and R.M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of Pembroke College Cambridge (2022) by kind permission of the author. Readers of this record are encouraged to consult Thomson's Catalogue for further information about this manuscript.

availability.p: Researchers should note that Pembroke College's western European medieval manuscripts are housed at Cambridge University Library (CUL). Scholars who wish to consult Pembroke College manuscripts should contact the Manuscripts Reading Room at CUL to arrange their visit; all CUL admissions procedures will apply. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library. For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

supportDesc.condition: Some minor staining to parchment, but no text lost to liquid damage.

layout.seg: Written in single-column format, typically 31 lines to the page. Most leaves are unruled, or ruling is frame only, but ff. 7r-8v are ruled frame and lines in leadpoint. Writing is mixed above and below top line.

handNote.p: Written in the anglicana form of cursiva antiquior.

decoNote.p: Inhabited initial with faces amid floral and foliate motifs on f. 7r. Puzzle initial, red and brown on f. 9r.
Occasional rubrication throughout ff. 1r-20v, typically mminor initials touched with red, and the use of red to underline particular sections of text.

additions.note: In the upper margin of f. 1r in ink: 'Jesus Maria + 1528'

msItem.title: Poem

note.p:
Full transcription
Fama repleta malis leuibus circumuolat alis
Fama boni lente uolat inuida retinente

listBibl.bibl: WIC 6260

msItem.title: Poem

note.p:
Full transcription:
Nescio si scis quo pacto mereatur episco
Pus . norwicensis . ut fiat Wintoniensis

msItem.title: Poem

note.p:
Full transcription:
Mittitur in disco mihi piscis ab archiepisco
Po . non inclino . quia missio fit sine uino

It is possible that poems 4 and 5 should be read as a single poem, i.e.,
Nescio si scis quo pacto mereatur episco
Pus . norwicensis . ut fiat Wintoniensis
Mittitur in disco mihi piscis ab archiepisco
Po . non inclino . quia missio fit sine uino
Both the fourth and fifth poem have the word for archbishop in Latin (archiepiscopus -i) as the final word in the first line of a couplet, and add an unusual break in the word so that the final syllable begins the second line of the couplet.

collation.p:
Three quires (Quires 2-4), the second and third quires with cancelled leaves.
Quire 210 (ff. 21-30)

handNote.p: Written in a northern textualis rotunda.
Medical recipes on f. 44v added in a 16th century secretary hand.

decoNote.p: Rubricated headings (red only) and titles for (unfinished) illustrations throughout.

additions.note: Annotations in a large hand in pencil or crayon in most margins. Annotations have been washed or rubbed off and are now very faint.

layout.seg: Arranged in double-column format, typically 55 lines to the column. Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, and written below top line.

decoNote.p: Sketches of mythical beasts (e.g. mermaid on f. 66v, centaur on f. 67v), grotesques, animals, human figures and other drolleries, in crayon, in the lower and outer margins of ff. 58r-90v. Many overwritten by subsequent marginal notes.
Puzzle initial with a face in the counterspace and pen-flourishing on f. 58r.
Flourished initials in red at the major and minor divisions of the text ff. 58r-90v.
Rubrication (red only) specifying headings and topics in the margins of ff. 58r-90v.
Guide letters for decorative initials in the margins of ff. 58r-90v.

additions.note: Marginal notes in several hands, including the main scribe ff. 58r-90v.

Bergsagel, D. Hiley and T. Riis (Copenhagen, 2015), pp. 223-250, esp. p. 233

p.secFol: 93r factus est quia prior me erat . et

collation.p:
4 quires of 8 leaves - 6th and 7th leaves cancelled from Quire 11, a leaf added after the 8th leaf of Quire 13:
Quire 108 (ff. 92-99)
Quire 118-2 (ff. 100-105; 6th and 7th leaves cancelled)
Quire 128 (ff. 106-113)
Quire 138+1 (ff. 114-122; 1 leaf added after the 8th leaf) |

supportDesc.condition: Leaves trimmed; minor losses to text and music on f. 122v

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Text is glossed and each page is divided into three unequal columns. Main text is written in a single central column on alternate lines, typically 25-26 lines to the column. Written above top line.

Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Text is glossed and each page is divided into three unequal columns. Gloss is written in two columns, one either side of the central column of main text. Ruling, and particularly column width varies per leaf, and gloss occasionally extends into non-ruled spaces and interlinearly into the main text.

handNote.p: Main text is written in an English protogothic bookhand, gloss is written in both a libraria and a more current form of the script by at least two scribes.

decoNote.p: Unfilled space for a decorative initial on f. 92r.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 12th century, almost certainly after 1173
origin.p: Likely terminus ante quem non provided by the music on f. 122v, a responsory for the commemmoration of Thomas Becket. As the responsory chant is the final item in this section, it could have been added after the other texts, but all texts were probably added within a quarter-century of one another.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 7 - Miscellaneous texts including notes on the sacraments

msContents.textLang: Old French, Latin and Middle English

msItem.title: Excerpts from the 'Si scienter' variant of a treatise on confession
msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.rubric: 123r Iste circumstancie circa confessionem sunt inquirenda De quibus penitencie sunt arbitrarie etc etc
msItem.incipit: 123r Item si scienter fuisti superbus transgrediendo mandata Dei
msItem.explicit: 126r Item si maledixeris patri compatri seu commatri

note.p: Quire 14 (ff. 123-126) comprises two folded bifolia that have been sewn together sequentially rather than in a typical 'nested bifolia' arrangement. The second bifolium, comprising the present ff. 125-126, has been sewn to the first bifolium (ff. 123-124) 'inside out', reversing the original copying sequence of the leaves in the bifolium; the correct arrangement for the leaves in Quire 14 should be ff. 123, 124, 126, 125.

See Goering and Mantello 'Early Penitential Writings of Robert Grosseteste' for discussion of this text and its complex transmission. In the article, Goering and Mantello state that the text in MS 258 has been 'heavily interpolated with extraneous materials' in comparison to the standard form of the text.

listBibl.bibl: J. Goering and F. A. C. Mantello, 'The Early Penitential Writings of Robert Grosseteste', Recherches de Théologie Ancienne et Médiévale, vol. 54, 1987, pp. 52–112

msItem.title: Notes on the seven deadly sins
msItem.incipit:
126r Superbia
Est non habere pudorem de malo aperto
msItem.explicit: 126r corpore et corde et de uerbis et tales vocabuntur filii dei

note.p: Superbia, inuidia, ira, accidia, auaricia, gulositas (for gula), luxuria

Quire 14 (ff. 123-126) comprises two folded bifolia that have been sewn together sequentially rather than in a typical 'nested bifolia' arrangement. The second bifolium, comprising the present ff. 125-126, has been sewn to the first bifolium (ff. 123-124) 'inside out', reversing the original copying sequence of the leaves in the bifolium; the correct arrangement for the leaves in Quire 14 should be ff. 123, 124, 126, 125.

msItem.title: Excerpts from a sermon on the decalogue attributed to Robert Grosseteste
msItem.incipit: 126v Non habebis deos alienos quia homo debet adorare solam maiestatem diuinam
msItem.explicit: 126v proximi violare cum non solum sit prohibitum mecari sed et illius concupis...

note.p: Text ends abruptly.
See McEvoy, 'Edition of a Sermon' for discussion of this text (not this MS) and its complex transmission.

Quire 14 (ff. 123-126) comprises two folded bifolia that have been sewn together sequentially rather than in a typical 'nested bifolia' arrangement. The second bifolium, comprising the present ff. 125-126, has been sewn to the first bifolium (ff. 123-124) 'inside out', reversing the original copying sequence of the leaves in the bifolium; the correct arrangement for the leaves in Quire 14 should be ff. 123, 124, 126, 125.

listBibl.bibl: James McEvoy, 'The Edition of a Sermon on the Decalogue Attributed to Robert Grosseteste, Recherches de Théologie et Philosophie Médiévales, vol. 68, no. 2, 2001, pp. 228–44

msItem.title: Text on vices
msItem.incipit:
125r Exultatio in adversis proximi
afflictio in prosperis proximi
periurium super librium
blasphefare proximium
msItem.explicit: 125v si volentes seruicium dei audire impeduisti

note.p: Begins abruptly, perhaps incomplete at the beginning.
Mise-en-page typical for verse; two columns on f. 125r, one column on f. 125v.

Quire 14 (ff. 123-126) comprises two folded bifolia that have been sewn together sequentially rather than in a typical 'nested bifolia' arrangement. The second bifolium, comprising the present ff. 125-126, has been sewn to the first bifolium (ff. 123-124) 'inside out', reversing the original copying sequence of the leaves in the bifolium; the correct arrangement for the leaves in Quire 14 should be ff. 123, 124, 126, 125.

msItem.title: Excerpt from chapter 4 of the Similitudines Anselmi
msItem.author: pseud-Anselm of Canterbury
msItem.incipit: 125v Uisus ad recta uidenda
msItem.explicit: 125v Pedes ad ambulanda quo debent

note.p: Longer version in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Laud Misc. 502, ff. 5r-51r, esp. f. 5rb

Quire 14 (ff. 123-126) comprises two folded bifolia that have been sewn together sequentially rather than in a typical 'nested bifolia' arrangement. The second bifolium, comprising the present ff. 125-126, has been sewn to the first bifolium (ff. 123-124) 'inside out', reversing the original copying sequence of the leaves in the bifolium; the correct arrangement for the leaves in Quire 14 should be ff. 123, 124, 126, 125.

msItem.title: Extracts from the Mirour de seinte eglise [French]
msItem.author: Edmund Riche (Edmund of Abingdon)
msItem.textLang: Old French with occasional Latin and Middle English
msItem.incipit: 133r Les vii morteus peches sount iceus . Orgoyl . Enuye . Ire . Accide . Auarice . Glotonye . e . Lecherie
msItem.explicit: 131v e tes leures en le sauter . e tonn quer en marche chaitiuement es diuise etc

note.p: Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 258 is 'MS C5' in Wilshere's discussion of the text, and contains extracts from the so-called 'lay version' of the text. Note that MS 258 was not used in Wilshere's edition of this text.
Extracts from chapters 8, 11, 13, 14, 21-27, 17.

This text contains a verse fragment in Middle English (IMEV 2320 / DIMEV 3742), present in this manuscript on f. 129r:
Nou goht sunne wnder wode
ond me rewez marie þi bricte rude
Nou goz sunne vnder tre
ond me rewez marie þi sone ant þe etc
Quire 15 is misbound. The present f. 133, a singleton, is now bound as the last leaf in the quire, but was originally the first leaf in the quire.

listBibl.bibl: Text edited in A.D. Wilshere, Mirour de seinte eglyse (St Edmund of Abingdon's Speculum Eclesie), Anglo-Norman Texts 40 (London, 1982)
Dean and Boulton, Anglo-Norman Literature, no. 629
IMEV 2320
DIMEV 3742

msItem.title: Theological notes in Latin
msItem.incipit: 129v Primum ordinat ad patrem sed non habebis deos alienos
msItem.explicit: 130v Postea queritur quid sit affinitas Respondet non affinitas est personarium proximitas ex carnali copula proueniens omni carens parentela

note.p: Notes on the ten commandments, on the eucharist, on penance, on excommunication, extreme unction, and consanguinity. Seemingly not excerpts from the Speculum ecclesiae (the base text for the Mirour de saint eglise).

msItem.title: Theological note in Latin

note.p:
Full transcription:
Propter hoc ergo dicendum est quod orationes atque suffragia etiam non prosunt dampnatis et ad illud quod ... quod cantamus ut liberentur a penis infernis . dicendum quod pene inferni ibi non supp... pro penis inferni dampnatoris . set accipitur ibi infernus pro purgatorio igne . qui dicitur tartarus uel infernus propter conformitatem cuiusdam acerbitatis pene quod est in purgatorio quae maior est quam maxima quae possit excogitari in hoc mundo bonum est cum semper ut pro omnibus fiant orationes atque suffragia quia et si non valent eis pro quibus fiunt in valent cum eius qui faciunt amen

msItem.title: Diagrammatic note on the meaning of various lines of the Pater noster
Theological notes in Latin

note.p: Notes on baptism.

msItem.title: Manuel des péchés [French]
msItem.author: William de Wadington
msItem.incipit: 134r Seynte Gregorii pape de Rome
msItem.explicit: 134v Ceo dist le prestre tauerner etc

note.p: The poem was edited (not from this MS) for the Roxburghe Club by F. J. Furnivall (London, 1862); the lines of the poem in Pembroke College MS 258 correspond with ll. 4446-4475, 5106-5143, 5264-5293, 5336-5361 in the edition.
The text on f. 134r is badly damaged due to rubbing.

134v þe þridde is mi moste kare
þat I . ne woot woder I scal fare

msItem.title: This world him plaineth of mickle untrue [Middle English verse]

note.p:
Heus plebs conqueritur quod pauca fides reperitur
Lex uiris moritur fraus regnat amor sepelitur
þis world hym pleyneȝ of mikel ontrewe
Ryt is ded ant þat is reweze
Falsnesse regnez ant is aboue
Non is biried trew loue

listBibl.bibl: DIMEV 5787

msItem.title: Exemplary stories including the story of Egyptius and Baldath
msItem.incipit: 136v Relatum est mihi de duobus negotiatoribus
msItem.explicit: 141v solebant coronari etc

note.p: This text appears to derive from Petrus Alfonsi

msItem.title: Merry a time I tell in May [Middle English verse]

note.p:
Full transcription:
Cantus occidentalis
Myrie a tyme I telle In may
Wan bricte blosmen brekez on tre
þeise foules singez nyt ant day
In ilche grene is gamen an gle

listBibl.bibl: DIMEV 3486

note.p: It is not easy to distinguish the boundaries between some of the texts on ff. 134v-141v - a selection of the identifiable texts are listed here.

supportDesc.collation:
Three quires of differing size. Leaves in Quires 14 and 15 are misbound. Quire 14, a quire of four leaves (ff. 123-126), consists of two sequential rather than nested bifolia, and the second bifolium, the present ff. 125r-126v has been bound inside out; the leaves in Quire 14 should be read ff. 123, 124, 126, 125. Quire 15 is a quire of 7 leaves (ff. 127-133), comprising three nested bifolia and a singleton (f. 133) after the 6th leaf; the singleton is misbound and should be the first leaf in the quire; the leaves in Quire 15 should be read ff. 133, 127-132.
Quire 144 (ff. 123-126)
Quire 156+1 (ff. 127-133; 1 leaf added after the 6th)
Quire 168 (ff. 134-141)
supportDesc.condition: Leaves are lightly stained and torn and some text is faded due to rubbing and liquid damage.

layout.seg: Typically arranged in single-column format, although ff. 125r and 134r-136r are in double-columns. Ruling, where present, is in leadpoint, and is usually frame and lines. Script size and page use is informal: 35-50 lines to the column or page on most leaves. Written below top line.

decoNote.p: Head of a dog sketched on f. 140v.
Rubrication (red only) by underlining to highlight particular letters or passages.

note.p: At the bottom of f. 129r a note in Latin about why people must be baptised in water rather than wine, milk, or any other fluid.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 258 - binding and binding lining

msItem.locus: binding leaf i verso - paper - binding leaf iii recto - paper
msItem.title: Notes of miscellaneous fees and fines

note.p: These leaves were once used as a lining to strengthen and supply structure to the binding of Pembroke College, MS 258. The leaves were originally pasted together, but have become partially separated and some of the leaves are now free. Some of the text on the leaves is legible, but much is either badly damaged or obscured by overlapping fragments of other text.

The leaves contain dating clauses for various regnal years in the reign of Edward IV, King of England, (b. 1442, d. 1483) Edward IV, King of England, (b. 1442, d. 1483) (r. 4 March 1461 - 3 October 1470, then again 11 April 1471 - 9 April 1483)

Several names are visible on the leaves including:
John Gilberd
Agnes Quable
Doctor Uske
John Ffostar
John Wotton
Jacobus Gossope
Rogerus Pemberton
Thomas Marsshall
Ric Garreys sadelor
Georgius Saverey
R. Stile
John Child
Henricus Drawewett
Willelmus Wrothe
John Crowche smyth
John Undebynton
William Rede
Simon peyntor
John Curteys
Edmundus Kyrcheley
Johannes Barbor
Willelmus Carpenter
Several places in London on the south bank of the Thames are mentioned including Blakmanstrete, Kenstrete (Kent Street), Pety Aley (?Pepper Alley), Piper Aley (Pepper Alley), Suthwerk (Southwark).

support.material: A mix of paper, parchment and linen. All text-leaves in this Part are paper. No watermarks visible.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Stable, but in poor condition. The leaves in this Part were originally pasted together and used to line the binding of Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 258. Some of the leaves used for lining the binding of Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 258 have been partially separated and it is possible to read portions of the text on those leaves, but the leaves are oriented in several directions, are coated in adhesive and paper residue, and are often partially obscured by scraps of smaller paper fragments. The volume was conserved in 2024 and significant work was done to stabilise the binding and the binding lining leaves. The layers of the section of the binding over the rear of the volume, i.e., linen, lining fragments, limp-parchment are held in place with an acetate band when the volume is not in use.

handNote.p: Written in a a chancery Anglicana by several scribes.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

origin.p: Date of production based on the presence of several regnal dating clauses in the text that refer to the reign of Edward IV.

change.persName: Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures Project, Cambridge University Library
